comments:
This course provides a comprehensive background in biomaterials. It covers
surface properties, mechanical behavior, and tissue response of ceramics, polymers, and
metals used in the body. It also builds on this knowledge to address aspects of tissue
engineering, particularly the substrate component of engineered tissue and organs.
Many students found the course material very interesting – the contents were
“useful and relevant to the world of bioengineering.” However, the majority of students
complained about the “poorly written and confusing exam questions,” which solely
included multiple choices that did “not reflect students’ knowledge of content” and were
based on “how well you memorized the slides.” Some students were unsatisfied with the
readings that were “difficult to decipher” and “became optional” due to too many details.
Students understood the adjustments made by Professor Ducheyne in grading and
in the content of assignments due to the higher enrollment of the course this semester.
However, many of them commented that “it was never made very clear how the
individual exams/assignments were graded” and that they “never got a single assignment
back.” Some students thought that Professor Ducheyne had put a lot of effort into the
course, but some found that the professor “didn’t seem very interested in being a
lecturer.”
Students felt that “the course was not very interactive” because of the large class
size. One student commented “the workload has been very light,” and another student
complained that the course “just increased the general knowledge of the subject.” This
course is recommended for majors and the prerequisites are General Chemistry and Basic
Biomechanics.
